mcq.q: What is the fundamental process of exchanging information from a source to a destination?
Which component prepares the data into a suitable format for the channel?
Which component receives the signal and processes it for the recipient?
What generates the baseband signal (e.g., a microphone)?
Which step in ADC converts a continuous-time signal to a discrete-time signal?
Which step in ADC converts continuous-amplitude samples into discrete levels?
Which step in ADC maps quantized levels to binary codes?
What is the goal of the Source Encoder?
MP3 compression is an example of which process?
What is the goal of the Channel Encoder?
How does the Channel Encoder improve reliability?
Which block provides for efficient transmission over the channel?
The modulator impresses information onto which wave?
Which guided channel consists of two insulated copper wires twisted together?
Why are wires twisted in a Twisted Pair Cable?
Which cable has a central conductor, insulator, and a metallic shield?
What allows Coaxial Cable to have higher bandwidth than Twisted Pair?
What principle does Optical Fiber use to guide light signals?
Which channel offers bandwidths in Terabits/s?
What are hollow metallic structures used to guide high-frequency signals called?
Which is an example of an Unguided Channel?
What is an undesired effect from the environment that is usually uncontrollable?
What is the superposition of two or more signals called?
What is intentional interference aimed at destroying signal quality?
What is the information generated by the application called?
What is the physical representation of the data in the system?
Which combination is used in the traditional telephone system?
Voice over IP (VoIP) is an example of which combination?
Modems are an example of which combination?
Ethernet and Wi-Fi are examples of which combination?

tf.q: A communication system has three basic blocks: Transmitter, Channel, and Receiver.
The receiver prepares the data into a suitable format for the channel.
tf.correction: The transmitter prepares the data.

tf.q: Sampling converts a continuous-time signal to a discrete-time signal.
Quantization converts continuous-amplitude samples into infinite discrete levels.
tf.correction: It converts them into a finite set of discrete levels.

tf.q: Source encoding aims to represent the signal efficiently using as few bits as possible.
Channel encoding removes redundancy to compress the data.
tf.correction: Channel encoding adds redundancy to improve reliability.

tf.q: Optical fiber is immune to electromagnetic interference (EMI).
Waveguides are used to guide low-frequency signals.
tf.correction: Waveguides are used for high-frequency signals (microwaves).

tf.q: Noise is a controllable effect from the environment.
tf.correction: Noise is usually uncontrollable.

tf.q: Jamming is unintentional interference.
tf.correction: Jamming is intentional interference.

tf.q: Signal is the information generated by the application.
tf.correction: Data is the information; Signal is the physical representation.

tf.q: Voice over IP (VoIP) represents Analog Data carried by a Digital Signal.

mcq.q: What type of signal varies in a smooth fashion over time?
Which signal maintains a constant level for a period and then changes to another?
Which of the following is an example of a continuous signal?
Which fundamental signal describes a smooth, periodic oscillation?
What type of wave is used in digital systems to represent binary data?
What represents the peak value or maximum strength of a wave?
What is the unit of measurement for frequency?
What is defined as the number of cycles that occur per second?
What is the inverse of frequency?
What determines the starting point of the wave's cycle relative to time 0?
What is the range of frequencies that a signal contains called?
Which mathematical tool decomposes a complex signal into simple sine wave components?
What is a component of zero frequency called?
What is the difference between the upper and lower frequencies in a continuous band called?
What does higher bandwidth allow for?
A square wave is a composite of a sine wave with how many harmonics?
What is the bandwidth of an ideal digital signal?

tf.q: A continuous signal maintains a constant level for a period.
tf.correction: A discrete signal maintains a constant level; a continuous signal varies smoothly.

tf.q: A sine wave is used to represent analog signals.
A square wave is a continuous signal.
tf.correction: A square wave is a discrete signal.

tf.q: Higher amplitude means a stronger signal.
Period is the time it takes to complete one full cycle.
Phase represents the vertical shift of the wave.
tf.correction: Phase represents the horizontal shift relative to time 0.

tf.q: Fourier analysis decomposes a complex signal into square wave components.
tf.correction: It decomposes it into simple sine wave components.

tf.q: A DC component has a frequency of zero.
Bandwidth is measured in Watts.
tf.correction: Bandwidth is measured in Hertz (Hz).

tf.q: An ideal digital signal has infinite bandwidth.

mcq.q: What mechanism does light use to propagate through optical fiber?
Which region of the optical fiber has a higher refractive index?
What is the condition for Total Internal Reflection (TIR)?
Which of the following is a key advantage of optical fiber regarding interference?
What is the typical core size of Single-mode Fiber (SMF)?
What is the typical core size of Multimode Fiber (MMF)?
Which fiber type is suitable for very long distances (40 km+)?
Which fiber type is typically used for LANs and data centers?
How does light propagate in Multimode Fiber?
What is the definition of attenuation in optical fiber?
What causes attenuation in optical fiber?
What does attenuation limit in an optical system?
What is the definition of dispersion?
What is the primary impact of dispersion on the system?
What phenomenon occurs when overlapping pulses cause bit errors?
What is the formula for Attenuation (dB)?
Which type of dispersion occurs only in Multimode Fiber (MMF)?
What causes Modal Dispersion?
Which type of dispersion occurs in both SMF and MMF?
What causes Chromatic Dispersion?
opts: Different wavelengths traveling at different speeds
mcq.answer: Different wavelengths traveling at different speeds

mcq.q: Which dispersion occurs in SMF due to fiber imperfections affecting polarization states?
When do nonlinearities like FWM occur?
opts: When optical intensity is very low
When optical intensity is very high
mcq.answer: When optical intensity is very high

mcq.q: What does Four-Wave Mixing (FWM) create?
What is the negative effect of Four-Wave Mixing (FWM)?
What device is used to combine or split optical signals?
What component splits one input into N outputs?
What component combines N inputs into one output?
Which couplers can be used to design an 8-port splitter?
What type of networks use Passive Star Couplers (PSC)?
What is the formula for output power in an NxN Passive Star Coupler?
What describes how the input optical power is divided between output ports?
In the coupling ratio formula, what does P1 represent?

tf.q: The cladding has a higher refractive index than the core.
tf.correction: The core has a higher refractive index.

tf.q: Optical fiber uses electricity to transmit signals.
tf.correction: It uses light.

tf.q: Single-mode fiber supports higher bandwidth than multimode fiber.
Multimode fiber is used for distances up to 550 m.
Attenuation is caused by different signal components arriving at different times.
tf.correction: That is the cause of dispersion; attenuation is caused by absorption and scattering.

tf.q: Dispersion limits the maximum transmission distance.
tf.correction: Dispersion limits the data rate; Attenuation limits the distance.

tf.q: Single-mode fiber experiences higher attenuation/dispersion than multimode fiber.
tf.correction: SMF has lower attenuation/dispersion.

tf.q: Optical fiber is difficult to tap without detection.
Modal Dispersion occurs in Single Mode Fiber (SMF).
tf.correction: It occurs only in MMF.

tf.q: Chromatic Dispersion occurs in both SMF and MMF.
Polarization Mode Dispersion (PMD) is caused by different wavelengths traveling at different speeds.
tf.correction: It is caused by fiber imperfections affecting polarization states.

tf.q: Nonlinearities occur when optical intensity is very high.
Four-Wave Mixing (FWM) results in the creation of new wavelengths.
A Combiner (Nx1) splits one input into N outputs.
tf.correction: A Combiner combines N inputs into one output.

tf.q: Passive Star Couplers require external power to operate.
tf.correction: They are passive (no external power).

tf.q: An NxN PSC distributes input power equally among the output ports.
The coupling ratio for port 1 is defined as P1 / (P1 + P2).
2x1 couplers cannot be used to design splitters.
tf.correction: They can be used to design an 8-port splitter.

mcq.q: What does LASER stand for?
opts: Light Amplification by Stimulated Energy of Radiation
Light Amplification by Stimulated Emission of Radiation
Light Absorption by Stimulated Emission of Radiation
Light Amplification by Spontaneous Emission of Radiation
mcq.answer: Light Amplification by Stimulated Emission of Radiation

mcq.q: Which process enables a laser to produce intense beams of coherent light?
What is the lowest and most stable energy level in an atom?
What happens when electrons absorb energy?
opts: They move to the ground state
They move to a higher, unstable level
mcq.answer: They move to a higher, unstable level

mcq.q: What is the special excited state where electrons remain longer than usual?
What is the condition where more electrons occupy the excited state than the ground state?
Why is population inversion essential?
opts: It emits more light than it absorbs
mcq.answer: It emits more light than it absorbs

mcq.q: Which component supplies energy to excite electrons in a laser?
Through which component does the intense laser beam exit?
What determines the laser’s output frequency?
What happens when a photon passes near another excited electron?
Which type of laser is built using a p-n junction with reflective edges?
Which type of laser is essential in WDM networks?
What is the typical tuning range of a tunable laser?
What is the tuning time for tunable lasers?
What component contains multiple fixed-tuned lasers in one component?
What is a drawback of laser arrays?
What is the spectral width of the laser output called?
Which of the following is an example of frequency instability?
What do longitudinal modes represent?
Why are multiple longitudinal modes undesirable?

tf.q: Optical transmitters are essential components in an optical transmission system.
Coherent light consists of light with one or more specific frequencies.
In the excited state, electrons are stable and remain indefinitely.
tf.correction: They are unstable and quickly return to the ground state.

tf.q: Population inversion is achieved by applying energy to a quasi-stable medium.
The lasing medium must exhibit quasi-stable states.
The output mirror in a laser is a fully reflective mirror.
tf.correction: The output mirror is partially transmitting.

tf.q: Stimulated emission produces a coherent photon identical to the incident photon.
Tunable lasers can be tuned continuously or discretely.
Laser arrays allow for multiple simultaneous transmissions.
Laser arrays have tunable wavelengths.
tf.correction: Wavelengths are fixed and cannot be tuned.

tf.q: Single-longitudinal-mode lasers are preferred over multi-mode lasers.
Mode shifts are a form of frequency instability.

mcq.q: What is the process of changing a property of light to encode information called?
Which of the following is the simplest and most widely used optical modulation method?
In On-Off Keying (OOK), what does high light intensity represent?
Which modulation technique is suitable for long-distance and high-speed communication?
How many bits per symbol does QPSK carry?
Which modulation technique modifies both amplitude and phase?
How many bits per symbol does 16-QAM carry?
How many bits per symbol does 64-QAM carry?
Why is FSK rarely used in modern optics?
What is the purpose of an optical receiver?
Which component in the receiver chain converts light to electrical current?
Which component amplifies the weak current in the receiver chain?
Which component restores the original digital data in the receiver chain?
What does Direct Detection use to convert light intensity into electrical current?
Where is Direct Detection commonly used?
What does Coherent Detection combine the incoming signal with?
What does Coherent Detection detect?
How does Coherent Detection compensate for dispersion?
Which is a limitation of Coherent Detection?
What is the primary role of optical filters in WDM systems?
opts: Selectively allow or block specific wavelengths
mcq.answer: Selectively allow or block specific wavelengths

mcq.q: Which of the following is NOT a key characteristic of optical filters mentioned?
What type of filter allows only a specific wavelength range to pass?
What characterizes the structure of a Fiber Bragg Grating (FBG)?
opts: Periodic refractive index variation inside fiber core
mcq.answer: Periodic refractive index variation inside fiber core

mcq.q: What happens to the specific wavelength targeted by an FBG?
Which component is widely used for dispersion compensation?
Which filters are used in flexible WDM networks (e.g., ROADMs)?
How does a Mach-Zehnder Interferometer (MZI) cancel unwanted wavelengths?
How can an MZI be tuned?
What converts client signals into precise DWDM wavelengths?
What is the typical wavelength for DWDM signals mentioned?
Which component combines multiple wavelengths onto a single fiber?
Which component separates combined wavelengths back into individual channels?
What is the function of an OADM at an intermediate node?
opts: Drop a selected wavelength and add a new one
mcq.answer: Drop a selected wavelength and add a new one

mcq.q: What does an Optical Amplifier (EDFA) do?
opts: Boosts signal power to counteract attenuation
mcq.answer: Boosts signal power to counteract attenuation

mcq.q: Why is a Variable Optical Attenuator (VOA) used?
What is the purpose of a Dispersion Compensator (DCM)?
opts: Correct dispersion and restore pulse shape
mcq.answer: Correct dispersion and restore pulse shape

mcq.q: DCM helps reduce which impairment?

tf.q: Optical filters are used to selectively allow or block specific wavelengths.
Out-of-Band Rejection is a key characteristic of optical filters.
Fiber Bragg Gratings allow all wavelengths to pass through.
tf.correction: They reflect a specific wavelength; others pass through.

tf.q: Tunable Optical Filters are used in fixed WDM networks.
tf.correction: They are used in flexible WDM networks (e.g., ROADMs).

tf.q: MZI splits light into two arms with the same path lengths.
tf.correction: It splits light into two arms with different path lengths.

tf.q: MZI tuning by temperature has a fast response.
tf.correction: It has a slow response.

tf.q: A Transponder converts 1550 nm signals into 850 nm signals.
tf.correction: It converts client signals (e.g., 850/1310 nm) into DWDM wavelengths (1550 nm).

tf.q: Optical Demultiplexers combine multiple wavelengths onto a single fiber.
tf.correction: Multiplexers combine; Demultiplexers separate.

tf.q: EDFA boosts signal power to counteract attenuation.
Variable Optical Attenuators increase signal power.
tf.correction: They reduce power intentionally.

tf.q: Amplitude Shift Keying (ASK) is also known as On-Off Keying (OOK).
In OOK, binary 0 corresponds to high light intensity.
tf.correction: Binary 0 corresponds to low light intensity.

tf.q: PSK is more robust than ASK.
BPSK uses four phases.
tf.correction: BPSK uses two phases.

tf.q: QAM is used in high-speed systems due to its high spectral efficiency.
Direct detection can detect phase and frequency.
tf.correction: Direct detection cannot detect phase or frequency.

tf.q: Direct detection is simple and low cost.
Coherent detection supports advanced modulation like PSK and QAM.
Coherent detection requires frequency/phase synchronization with the Local Oscillator.
Direct detection has higher sensitivity than coherent detection.
tf.correction: Direct detection has lower sensitivity.

mcq.q: What component in a DWDM system converts a non-DWDM wavelength signal into a DWDM-compliant one?
The process where a transponder converts a signal from optical to electrical and back to optical is known as _______ conversion.
Which of these is NOT a primary function of a transponder?
Which wavelength is typically used on the terminal side for short-distance connections in multimode fiber systems?
Which wavelength is common for single-mode fiber over medium distances (up to 10 km)?
DWDM systems primarily operate in which optical spectrum band for its low attenuation?
What is the name of the component that allows light to pass in one direction but blocks it in the opposite direction?
Isolators are primarily used to protect which type of sensitive components from reflections?
In an optical _______, light entering a specific port exits from the next sequential port.
What device combines multiple optical signals of different wavelengths into a single beam?
What device performs the reverse function of a multiplexer by separating a combined signal into individual wavelengths?
A demultiplexer can be constructed using a circulator in combination with what other component?
What does OADM stand for?
An OADM is used at what point in a network to route specific channels?
What is the primary function of an Optical Attenuator?
opts: To control and reduce the power level of the signal
mcq.answer: To control and reduce the power level of the signal

mcq.q: Which type of attenuator provides a predetermined and unchangeable amount of attenuation?
Which type of attenuator allows for adjustable attenuation levels, useful in dynamic networks?

tf.q: A transponder's main job is to filter noise from a signal.
tf.correction: Its main job is signal and wavelength conversion.

tf.q: The L-band (1565-1625 nm) is sometimes used to expand the capacity of DWDM systems.
An optical isolator is a bi-directional device, allowing light to pass freely in both directions.
tf.correction: It is a uni-directional device, allowing light to pass in only one direction.

tf.q: In a 3-port circulator, light entering port 2 will exit from port 1.
tf.correction: It will exit from the next sequential port, which is port 3.

tf.q: A MUX and a DEMUX perform identical functions.
tf.correction: A DEMUX performs the reverse function of a MUX.

tf.q: An FBG used with a circulator for demultiplexing works by reflecting a specific wavelength.
An OADM is used to add or remove all wavelengths from a DWDM signal simultaneously.
tf.correction: It adds or removes specific wavelengths while allowing others to pass through.

tf.q: An optical attenuator is a type of amplifier.
tf.correction: It performs the opposite function; it reduces signal power.

tf.q: One reason to use an attenuator is to prevent the overloading of components like receivers.
A Variable Optical Attenuator (VOA) provides a fixed amount of attenuation.
tf.correction: It allows for adjustable attenuation levels.

tf.q: A Fixed Optical Attenuator is used in applications where the required attenuation level may change frequently.
tf.correction: It is used when a specific, unchanging level of signal reduction is needed.

mcq.q: What phenomenon causes the spreading of different wavelengths of light and signal degradation?
What is the name of the specialized fiber engineered with opposite dispersion characteristics to reverse broadening?
Standard Single-Mode Fiber (SMF) typically has which type of chromatic dispersion?
Dispersion Compensating Fiber (DCF) is designed to have which type of chromatic dispersion?
In the lecture example, 80 km of regular fiber is compensated by how much DCF?
What is the name of a device that amplifies an optical signal directly without converting it to an electrical signal?
Which of the following is NOT a type of optical amplifier listed in the lecture?
What element is used to dope the fiber in an EDFA?
An EDFA uses a _______ to stimulate the doped fiber and increase signal strength.
EDFAs are ideal for long-distance communication because they have _______ gain and _______ noise.
The pump laser for an EDFA typically operates at which wavelengths?
What component is placed at the end of an EDFA to avoid reflections?
A Regenerator performs 3R, which stands for _______.
An EDFA is known as a _______ device because it only re-amplifies the signal.
What is the main drawback of an Optical Amplifier compared to a Regenerator?
opts: It amplifies signal and noise together
It is more complex and costly
It converts the signal to electrical
mcq.answer: It amplifies signal and noise together

mcq.q: Which device provides a clean, fully restored signal by removing noise and reshaping the pulse?
What is the function of a Wavelength Converter (WC)?
opts: Converts input wavelength to another wavelength
Switches the signal to a different fiber
mcq.answer: Converts input wavelength to another wavelength

mcq.q: Which type of Wavelength Converter (WC) converts the signal from optical to electrical and back to optical?
Which type of WC relies on nonlinear optical effects and involves no electrical conversion?
Which WC technology has the advantage of signal regeneration (reshaping and retiming)?
Which WC technology is described as being ultrahigh-speed?
Which type of switching is currently employed in WDM optical networks?
What is the term for the fraction of power lost as a signal passes through an optical switch?
What term describes the ratio of power at the desired output vs. an undesired output in a switch?
What is the ratio of output power in the ON state to the power in the OFF state called?

tf.q: Chromatic dispersion causes optical pulses to sharpen and narrow.
tf.correction: It causes pulse broadening (spreading).

tf.q: Dispersion Compensating Fiber (DCF) works by having dispersion characteristics opposite to regular fiber.
SMF has negative chromatic dispersion, and DCF has positive chromatic dispersion.
tf.correction: SMF has positive, and DCF has negative.

tf.q: An optical amplifier must convert a signal to electrical form to amplify it.
tf.correction: It amplifies the signal directly in its optical form.

tf.q: Raman Amplifier is one type of optical amplifier.
An EDFA amplifies signals by using a fiber doped with erbium and a pump laser.
An isolator is used in an EDFA to couple the pump laser into the fiber.
tf.correction: It is placed at the end to avoid reflections.

tf.q: If an EDFA does not have an isolator, it may convert into a laser.
A regenerator is a 1R device.
tf.correction: It is a 3R device (Reamplify, Reshape, Retime).

tf.q: An EDFA performs 1R (Reamplify).
An EDFA can remove noise and reshape the signal pulse.
tf.correction: It amplifies both the signal and the noise.

tf.q: A Regenerator (O-E-O) provides a clean, fully restored signal.
Optical amplifiers are generally higher in cost and complexity than regenerators.
tf.correction: They are lower in cost and complexity.

tf.q: A Wavelength Converter (WC) is used to amplify an optical signal.
tf.correction: It converts the signal from one wavelength to another.

tf.q: OE-WC is an all-optical conversion method.
tf.correction: It is Optical-to-Electrical-to-Optical.

tf.q: Wavelength conversion using coherent effects provides signal regeneration.
tf.correction: No, it only transfers the wavelength.

tf.q: OE-WC speed is limited by electronic components.
Optical packet switching currently faces many challenges.
In a switch's 'bar state', the inputs are crossed to the opposite outputs.
tf.correction: This describes the 'cross state'.

tf.q: Crosstalk is the fraction of power lost when a signal passes through a switch.
tf.correction: That is Insertion Loss.

mcq.q: Which network generation (G1-G4) is described as 'Electronic' and uses copper cables?
In the G2 network generation, what is the 'Node Technology'?
Which network generation (G1-G4) introduced WDM as its 'Transmission Technology'?
Which network generation is still in research laboratories and aims for 'Optical' node technology?
In an 'All-Optical Network' diagram, what does OXC stand for?
What is the term for a full optical path from source to destination in a WDM network?
According to the graph, which capacity is growing faster: Optical Transmission Capacity or Electronic Switching Capacity?
The gap between the growth of fiber capacity and electronic switching capacity leads to what issue?
What was the first generation of WDM networks deployed in the early to mid 90's?
Today's common channel count for Point-to-Point WDM systems is _______.
Which generation of WDM networks allows adding/dropping data streams at intermediate points?
Which generation of WDM systems marked the birth of a true 'WDM networking' infrastructure?
Which of these is NOT a category of optical interconnection device listed?
What device splits the power of an input signal on one fiber equally among all output fibers?
What problem occurs in a Passive Star if two signals on the same wavelength arrive from different input fibers simultaneously?
Which device routes optical signals based on a fixed, predetermined 'routing matrix'?
Which of the following is another name for a Passive Router?
What is the key difference between an Active Switch and a Passive Router?
opts: Active Switch has a reconfigurable routing matrix
Passive Router has a reconfigurable matrix
mcq.answer: Active Switch has a reconfigurable routing matrix

mcq.q: What is the name for an Active Switch?
What limitation of an Active Switch can be overcome by using wavelength converters?
opts: Being 'blocking' (e.g., cannot route two same-wavelength inputs to one output)
mcq.answer: Being 'blocking' (e.g., cannot route two same-wavelength inputs to one output)

mcq.q: According to the comparison table, which device is passive and simply splits signals?
According to the comparison table, which device is active and can reconfigure paths in real time?
Which device has 'Fixed paths; limited routing capability' according to the comparison table?
Which device is 'Highly scalable' and suited for data centers and metro networks?
Which device is suited for Fiber-to-the-home (FTTH) and has low flexibility?

tf.q: The G1 network generation used optical fiber as its transmission medium.
tf.correction: It used copper cables.

tf.q: The G3 network generation is currently deployed in backbone networks (WANs).
The G4 network aims to have electronic node technology.
tf.correction: It aims for optical node technology.

tf.q: Electronic switching capacity (Moore's Law) is growing faster than optical transmission capacity.
tf.correction: Optical transmission capacity is growing faster.

tf.q: The first generation of WDM networks was Wavelength Add/Drop Multiplexers.
tf.correction: It was Point-to-Point WDM systems.

tf.q: The maximum channel count for Point-to-Point WDM is 64.
tf.correction: The maximum channel count today is 160.

tf.q: A WADM provides the flexibility to add/drop data streams at intermediate points.
A WADM consists of a MUX, followed by switches, followed by a DEMUX.
tf.correction: It consists of a DEMUX, followed by switches, followed by a MUX.

tf.q: Passive Star, Passive Router, and Active Switch are all categories of optical interconnection devices.
A Passive Star routes signals based on wavelength to specific outputs.
tf.correction: It splits the power of an input signal equally among all output fibers.

tf.q: A collision occurs in a Passive Star if two different wavelengths are launched simultaneously.
tf.correction: It occurs if two signals on the same wavelength are launched.

tf.q: A Passive Router has a reconfigurable routing matrix.
tf.correction: Its routing matrix is fixed.

tf.q: AWG (Arrayed Waveguide Grating) is another name for an Active Switch.
tf.correction: It is another name for a Passive Router.

tf.q: An Active Switch has a fixed routing matrix, similar to a Passive Router.
tf.correction: It has a reconfigurable routing matrix.

tf.q: An Active Switch can direct the same wavelength from different input fibers to any of the output fibers.
Active switches are 'non-blocking' and can always connect an input to any output.
tf.correction: They can be 'blocking' under some configurations.

tf.q: An Active Switch cannot connect input signals on the same wavelength to the same output fiber.
Using wavelength converters can overcome the blocking limitations of Active Switches.
Passive devices (Star, Router) require external power to operate.
tf.correction: They are passive and do not require power.

tf.q: An Active Switch has low flexibility and a fixed configuration.
tf.correction: It has high flexibility and a dynamic configuration.

tf.q: Passive Routers are highly scalable and used in data centers.
tf.correction: Active Switches are.

mcq.q: Wavelength-Routed Networks are also known as _______.
In an OCS network, what is the circuit (path) commonly called?
The main problem in Wavelength-Routed Networks is the _______ problem.
What is the goal of the WRA problem?
opts: Establish the maximum number of lightpaths
mcq.answer: Establish the maximum number of lightpaths

mcq.q: Which of these is NOT a Routing Problem strategy mentioned?
Which routing strategy uses the shortest path, such as Dijkstra's algorithm?
Which of these is NOT a Wavelength Assignment strategy?
Which wavelength assignment strategy involves choosing the 'Most-Used' wavelength?
The mismatch between switching capability and optical transmission capacity leads to the _______.
What does OPS stand for?
Design of a truly OPS architecture requires advances in Optical Memory and _______.
In OPS, what occurs when two packets try to leave the same output port, on the same wavelength, at the same time?
How do electrical packet-switched networks typically resolve contention?
Since there is no optical RAM, OPS can use 'Optical Buffers' which are implemented using _______.
Besides Optical Buffers (FDL), what other technology can be used for contention resolution in OPS?
What network architecture presents a compromise between OCS and OPS?
What is the key idea of OBS?
opts: Direct bursts without electronics for routing decisions
Store all bursts in optical RAM
Use OEO processing at every node
mcq.answer: Direct bursts without electronics for routing decisions

mcq.q: In OBS, which node is responsible for 'Optical burst generation'?
In OBS, which node is responsible for 'Data burst disassembly'?
In OBS, which node performs 'Control packet lookup' and 'Switching'?
In OBS, what is the time separation between the 'Control packet' and the 'Data burst' called?
The procedure for aggregating data packets into bursts at the edge of an OBS network is called _______.
Which burst assembly algorithm generates a burst after a fixed time has passed?
Which burst assembly algorithm generates a burst when a specific number of packets or burst length is reached?
Which burst assembly algorithm combines timer and threshold methods?
What is the drawback of a timer-based scheme if the timeout value is too small?
What is the drawback of a threshold-based assembly algorithm?
Which algorithm is responsible for adjusting the offset time and scheduling bursts on output links?
Which of the following is a scheduling technique mentioned for OBS?
Which of the following is NOT a signaling protocol for OBS mentioned in the lecture?

tf.q: Wavelength-Routed Networks are a type of Optical Packet Switching.
tf.correction: They are a type of Optical Circuit Switching.

tf.q: In OCS, a circuit (path) is established after the data is streamed.
tf.correction: It is established in a set-up phase before the data.

tf.q: The WRA problem involves both a Routing Problem and a Wavelength Assignment Problem.
'Fixed-Alternate Routing' is a strategy for the Wavelength Assignment problem.
tf.correction: It is a strategy for the Routing Problem.

tf.q: 'First-Fit (FF)' is a strategy for the Wavelength Assignment problem.
WDM electronic switches have become bottlenecks due to their high speed and small size.
tf.correction: They are bottlenecks due to their (limited) Size and Speed.

tf.q: OPS processes packets in the electronic domain.
tf.correction: It processes packets in the optical domain.

tf.q: A key challenge for OPS is the lack of optical RAM.
Contention in OPS can be resolved using Wavelength Converters (WC).
FDL stands for Fiber Delay Line.
Optical Burst Switching (OBS) is a compromise between OCS and OPS.
OBS requires OEO processing at every core node for routing decisions.
tf.correction: It avoids electronics for routing data bursts.

tf.q: In OBS, the Data Burst is sent before the Control Packet.
tf.correction: The Control Packet is sent first.

tf.q: The Core node in an OBS network performs 'Data burst disassembly'.
tf.correction: The Egress node does.

tf.q: The Ingress node in an OBS network makes the 'Offset-time decision'.
Burst assembly algorithms are classified as timer-based and threshold-based only.
tf.correction: Also mixed timer/threshold-based.

tf.q: In a timer-based scheme, a large timeout value can lead to higher control overhead.
tf.correction: It can lead to intolerable packet delay.

tf.q: Threshold-based assembly algorithms provide a strong guarantee on packet delay.
tf.correction: They do not provide any guarantee on the assembly delay.

tf.q: Mixed timer/threshold-based assembly algorithms have a lower operational complexity.
tf.correction: They have a higher operational complexity.

tf.q: Burst scheduling is performed at the Egress node.
tf.correction: It is performed at the Ingress node.

tf.q: LAUC (Latest Available Unused Channel) is a type of burst assembly algorithm.
tf.correction: It is a burst-scheduling technique.

tf.q: A signaling protocol in OBS can be one-way or two-way.
Just In Time (JIT) is a burst assembly algorithm.
tf.correction: It is a signaling protocol.

mcq.q: What is the access network also known as?
What does the access network connect?
Which of these is NOT another name for the access network?
What are the predominant broadband access solutions deployed today?
DSL and CATV infrastructures were originally built for carrying voice and _______ signals, respectively.
What is the distance limitation of DSL due to signal distortions?
What does VDSL stand for?
VDSL can support up to _______ of downstream bandwidth.
What is the maximum distance limitation for VDSL?
How do CATV networks provide Internet services?
What is a major limitation of CATV networks?
opts: Network performance degrades at high load
mcq.answer: Network performance degrades at high load

mcq.q: At best, ADSL2+ provides _______ of downstream bandwidth and _______ of upstream bandwidth.
What part of the network is described as a 'bottleneck for providing broadband services'?
Next-generation access networks are based on what technology?
What does FTTB stand for?
According to the comparison graph, which technology offers both the highest line rate and the longest reach distance?
What is the logical topology for deploying fiber shown in scenario 1?
In a PtP design with N subscribers at distance L, how many transceivers are required?
In a PtP design with N subscribers at distance L, what is the total fiber length required?
What is the main drawback of the curb-switched network architecture?
opts: Requires electrical power at the curb switch
mcq.answer: Requires electrical power at the curb switch

mcq.q: In the curb-switched scenario (scenario 2), how many transceivers are required?
What is the topology of a Passive Optical Network (PON)?
How many transceivers are required for a PON design with N subscribers?
A PON employs what passive device to split and combine optical power?
An optical coupler consists of two _______ together.
Which of these is NOT listed as a PON topology?
What does OLT stand for?
What does ONU stand for?
Where does the OLT reside?
The ONU is located at the end-user location in which FTTx model?
What is the maximum operating distance for PONs mentioned as an advantage?
How does a PON operate in the downstream, allowing for services like video broadcasting?

tf.q: The access network is also known as the 'first-mile' network.
The 'local loop' connects two service provider central offices (COs).
tf.correction: It connects COs to subscribers.

tf.q: DSL and CATV infrastructures were originally designed to carry data.
tf.correction: They were built for voice and analog TV, respectively.

tf.q: The distance limit for DSL is 1500 feet.
tf.correction: It is 18000 feet.

tf.q: VDSL can support up to 50 Mbps, but its maximum distance is limited to 1500 feet.
CATV networks were mainly built for distributing access bandwidth, not broadcast services.
tf.correction: They were mainly built for delivering broadcast services.

tf.q: The access network is considered a bottleneck for providing broadband services.
Next-generation access networks are based on VDSL technology.
tf.correction: They are based on Passive Optical Network (PON).

tf.q: FTTx stands for 'Fiber-to-the-Transceiver'.
tf.correction: It stands for 'Fiber-to-the-...' (e.g., Home, Office, Building).

tf.q: In the comparison graph, PON has a lower line rate than VDSL.
tf.correction: It has a significantly higher line rate.

tf.q: A point-to-point (PtP) topology requires 2N transceivers for N subscribers.
A curb-switched network (scenario 2) requires N x L total fiber length.
tf.correction: It requires L km of fiber (assuming negligible distance from switch to customers).

tf.q: A curb switch is a passive device that requires no electrical power.
tf.correction: It is an active device that requires electrical power and back-up power.

tf.q: PON is a point-to-point (PtP) optical network.
tf.correction: It is a point-to-multipoint (PtMP) network.

tf.q: A PON has active elements in the signal path from source to destination.
tf.correction: It has no active elements in the signal path.

tf.q: A PON design requires N+1 transceivers for N subscribers.
A PON design requires L km of fiber for N subscribers at distance L.
An optical coupler can only split signals from one fiber into several, it cannot combine them.
tf.correction: It can also combine signals from multiple fibers into one.

tf.q: The OLT (Optical Line Terminal) resides at the customer's premises.
tf.correction: It resides in the CO (Central Office).

tf.q: The ONU (Optical Network Unit) connects the access network to the MAN or backbone network.
tf.correction: The OLT does.

tf.q: A PON can operate at distances up to 20 km.
A PON operates as a broadcast network in the upstream direction.
tf.correction: It operates as a broadcast network in the downstream.

mcq.q: Which of the following is NOT a suitable topology for PON deployment mentioned in the lecture?
The phenomenon where power levels received at the OLT differ due to unequal ONU distances is called the _______.
Which device in a TDM PON requires a burst-mode receiver?
Why is a burst-mode receiver necessary at the OLT?
opts: To adjust the zero-one threshold for each timeslot
mcq.answer: To adjust the zero-one threshold for each timeslot

mcq.q: What is an alternative solution to using a burst-mode receiver at the OLT?
EPON carries data traffic encapsulated in _______.
In EPON downstream, how does an ONU extract its specific packets from the broadcast stream?
What is the typical range for the splitting ratio (N) in EPON?
In the upstream direction of a PON, frames from different ONUs may _______.
What mechanism is required in the upstream direction of EPON to share channel capacity?
A WDM-PON creates a _______ link between the OLT and each ONU.
Unlike basic PONs, WDM-PONs do not suffer from _______.
Which component is commonly used in WDM PON designs to route wavelengths?
In CPON (Composite PON), how is the upstream channel shared?
What technology allows CPON to support upstream and downstream on a single fiber?
In the LARNET architecture, what device is used at the ONU for transmission?

tf.q: PONs can be deployed in tree, ring, or bus topologies.
In a PON, optical signal attenuation is identical for all ONUs.
tf.correction: Attenuation varies due to unequal distances.

tf.q: A receiver adjusted for a strong signal might mistake zeros for ones when receiving a weak signal.
tf.correction: It may mistakenly read ones as zeros.

tf.q: ONUs require burst-mode receivers to read data from the OLT.
tf.correction: ONUs read a continuous bit stream; only OLT needs burst-mode.

tf.q: EPON carries data traffic encapsulated in Ethernet frames.
In EPON downstream, data is broadcast to all ONUs.
In EPON upstream, data frames from one ONU are visible to other ONUs.
tf.correction: Directional properties of the combiner prevent this.

tf.q: WDM-PON suffers from high power-splitting losses like basic PONs.
tf.correction: It does not suffer power-splitting losses.

tf.q: WDM-PON allows different ONUs to operate at different bit rates.
In CPON, the upstream uses WDM.
tf.correction: Upstream uses a single wavelength shared via TDMA.

tf.q: LARNET stands for Local Access Remote Network.
Most WDM PON designs make use of AWGs (Arrayed Waveguide Gratings).

mcq.q: Where does the optical domain end and the electrical domain resume?
What is the primary purpose of the optical receiver?
opts: To convert photons into an electronic signal
mcq.answer: To convert photons into an electronic signal

mcq.q: What are the two main functional blocks of an optical receiver?
Which effect occurs when a photon with sufficient energy hits a semiconductor material?
Which of the following is NOT a required feature for a photodetector?
What is the term for the minimum optical power required to maintain an acceptable BER?
Which noise source arises from the discrete nature of electron flow (randomness in photon arrival)?
Which noise source is caused by random thermal motion of electrons in resistive components?
Which noise is dominant in PIN receivers?
What does TIA stand for in receiver electronics?
What is the function of the TIA?
Which stage decides whether the pulse represents a '1' or a '0'?
Which system degradation factor affects the Power Budget?
Which system degradation factor affects the Rise Time/Bandwidth Budget?
What nonlinear effect generates new, unwanted frequencies (crosstalk)?
What nonlinear effect transfers power from one wavelength channel to another?
System margin is included to account for _______.
What is a typical value for the commercial design system margin?
Which budget determines if the signal has enough power to be detected accurately?
In the power budget equation, what represents the Available Power/Gain?
The Rise Time Budget focuses on which domain?
What occurs if the pulse spreads beyond the maximum allowable rise time?
For NRZ modulation, what is the approximate relationship for T_sys?
What formula is used for combining rise times in the budget?
The system's maximum operational distance is governed by _______.
opts: The most restrictive result from either budget
The least restrictive result from either budget
mcq.answer: The most restrictive result from either budget

tf.q: The primary purpose of the optical receiver is to convert electrons into photons.
tf.correction: It converts photons into electrons (current).

tf.q: The received optical power is often extremely low.
The photoconductive effect creates an electron-hole pair.
Receiver sensitivity is the maximum optical power the receiver can handle.
tf.correction: It is the minimum optical power required.

tf.q: Shot noise is caused by the random thermal motion of electrons.
tf.correction: Thermal noise is caused by thermal motion; Shot noise is from discrete electron flow.

tf.q: The TIA's design dictates the noise floor of the entire system.
Attenuation leads to a loss of signal fidelity or speed.
tf.correction: Attenuation leads to loss of power; Dispersion leads to loss of fidelity.

tf.q: EDFAs, DCMs, and VOAs are used to mitigate system degradation effects.
In high-power systems, the fiber's refractive index becomes dependent on optical power.
System margin is a type of loss that degrades the signal.
tf.correction: It is a safety factor, not a physical loss.

tf.q: The Link Budget must pass two critical tests: Power Budget and Rise Time Budget.
Fixed Losses in a power budget include the variable fiber loss.
tf.correction: Fixed losses include splices, connectors, components, and margin.

tf.q: The Rise Time Budget ensures the signal is not too spread out.
T_Dispersion is calculated using only the fiber's dispersion parameter (D).
tf.correction: It uses D and the source's spectral width.

tf.q: The final system limit is determined by whichever budget allows for a longer distance.
tf.correction: It is determined by the most restrictive (shorter distance) result.

mcq.q: What does Radio Frequency (RF) refer to?
What is the typical frequency range of the RF electromagnetic spectrum?
What category of waves in the spectrum has the longest wavelength?
Which wave category follows Ultraviolet in the direction of decreasing wavelength?
What is the speed of RF waves in a vacuum?
How is 3 kHz to 30 kHz RF classified?
What is the frequency range for Medium RF (Low Frequency - LF)?
High RF (300 kHz to 30 MHz) includes which frequency classifications?
Which application uses RF for accurate positioning?
In medical use, RF waves are employed in which machines?
How is Radio Frequency generated?
What sends the generated RF signal through a medium?
What does AIDC stand for?
AIDC methods directly enter data into computer systems without _______.
Barcodes and QR codes are examples of which AIDC component?
Which of the following is a data capture device?
What transmits captured AIDC data to a processing system?
Which system interprets and manages collected AIDC data?
Magnetic stripe cards are a type of _______.
What does RFID technology use to identify and track objects?
RFID allows for automated data collection without physical contact or _______.
What is the technical name for an RFID tag?
What is the technical name for an RFID reader?
Which part of an RFID tag stores data and unique identifiers?
Which RFID tag type has no internal power source?
What powers an active RFID tag?
Which RFID reader component combines transmitter and receiver functions?
Which component of an RFID reader processes tag data?
Which software eliminates duplicate or redundant RFID data?
How are passive tags powered?

tf.q: RF waves travel at approximately 300,000 km/s in a vacuum.
Radio frequencies fall between 3 kHz and 300 GHz.
RF generation occurs by oscillating a current in an electronic circuit.
AIDC methods require manual data entry to improve accuracy.
tf.correction: AIDC enters data directly without manual entry.

tf.q: Wi-Fi and Bluetooth are examples of AIDC communication channels.
RFID technology requires physical contact to identify objects.
tf.correction: RFID works without physical contact or line-of-sight.

tf.q: A semi-passive tag uses a battery to power its chip but relies on the reader's signal for communication.
The tag antenna is responsible for sending RF signals to activate tags.
tf.correction: The reader antenna sends signals to activate tags.

tf.q: Middleware is responsible for data filtering and system integration.
Ethernet and USB are wired communication interface examples for RFID readers.

mcq.q: Which component of an RFID tag transmits and receives RF signals?
Unlike RFID, barcode technology requires _______ to decode information.
What is the typical read range for Passive UHF RFID tags?
Which technology allows data to be updated on the carrier?
Which of the following is a disadvantage of Barcodes compared to RFID?
RFID is ideal for which type of scanning?
In a Passive Tag workflow, what powers the microchip?
What method do passive tags use to transmit data back to the reader?
Which type of tag uses an internal battery to transmit signals directly to the reader?
In a Semi-Passive tag, what is the battery used for?
What is the approximate cost range for a Passive Tag?
What is the typical tag life for a Passive RFID tag?
Active tags are capable of recognizing thousands of tags at speeds up to _______.
Which frequency band operates at 125-134 KHz?
Low Frequency (LF) tags require which type of antenna?
What is a key advantage of Low Frequency (LF) tags?
opts: Not absorbed by water and tissue
mcq.answer: Not absorbed by water and tissue

mcq.q: What is a disadvantage of Low Frequency (LF) tags?
Ultra High Frequency (UHF) tags typically operate in which range?
What is the main application mentioned for UHF passive tags?
UHF antennas are _______ providing a controlled read zone.
UHF signals have difficulty penetrating which materials?
Which frequency band is typically 13.56 MHz?
High Frequency (HF) tags are commonly used for _______.
What is the typical read range for High Frequency (HF) tags?
Which frequency band offers 'Very High' data rates?
Animal tagging and car keys typically use which frequency band?
What factor influences the choice of RFID frequency?
Active tags typically have a read range of _______.
Which tag type is described as 'More thicker and expensive than 13.56 MHz'?
What is a disadvantage of UHF readers compared to HF readers?

tf.q: Barcodes require line-of-sight to be scanned.
RFID tags can store more data than barcodes.
Passive RFID tags have an internal battery.
tf.correction: Passive tags have no internal battery.

tf.q: Active RFID tags rely on the reader's signal to power their transmission.
tf.correction: Active tags use an internal battery for transmission.

tf.q: Semi-passive tags use a battery to power the chip but rely on the reader for communication.
Low Frequency (LF) tags are absorbed by water and tissue.
tf.correction: LF does not get absorbed by water and tissue.

tf.q: UHF tags are effective around metals.
The typical read range for LF tags is up to 12 meters.
tf.correction: LF range is up to 10 cm.

tf.q: High Frequency (HF) tags have a higher interference sensitivity than LF tags.
Active tags are generally cheaper than passive tags.
tf.correction: Active tags are significantly more expensive ($20+).

mcq.q: What is the UHF frequency standard range for North America (US/Canada)?
What is the UHF frequency standard range for Europe?
Which region corresponds to Europe under global regulations?
Which regulatory body governs Region 2 (USA)?
Which country uses the frequency range 952-955 MHz?
What communication method do passive tags use to avoid having a transmitter?
What does a 3 dB loss in a cable correspond to?
A 20 dB gain corresponds to a signal increase by a factor of _______.
What is the reference power for the unit 'dBm'?
Which power level in Watts corresponds to 30 dBm?
What does EIRP stand for?
In the EIRP formula, the antenna gain ($G_{antenna}$) is measured in _______.
What does ERP stand for?
ERP assumes the antenna radiates relative to which standard?
What is the conversion factor between dBi and dBd?
The FCC standard limits power to _______.
The ETSI standard limits power to _______.
If a transmitter outputs 20 dBm, Antenna Gain is 5 dBi, and Cable Loss is 2 dB, what is the EIRP?
If the EIRP is 36 dBm, what is the equivalent ERP?
If the ERP is 33 dBm, what is the equivalent EIRP?
Convert 40 dBm to dBW.
What is 10 Watts expressed in dBm?
Calculate the ERP (in dBm) if Transmitter Power = 30 dBm, Antenna Gain = 4 dBd, and Line Loss = 1 dB.
If a signal of 100 mW goes through a cable with 10 dB loss, what is the output power?
To convert from dBm to dBW, you must _______.

tf.q: Region 1 in global standards refers to the USA.
tf.correction: Region 1 refers to Europe; Region 2 is USA.

tf.q: Backscatter radio allows a tag to communicate without transmitting its own signal.
A 10 dB loss corresponds to a 50% decrease in signal level.
tf.correction: 10 dB loss corresponds to a 90% decrease; 3 dB loss is 50%.

tf.q: dBm is a logarithmic measure of power referenced to 1 watt.
tf.correction: dBm is referenced to 1 milliwatt (1mW).

tf.q: EIRP assumes the antenna radiates equally in all directions.
The conversion formula is ERP = EIRP + 2.15 dB.
tf.correction: ERP = EIRP - 2.15 dB.

tf.q: Antenna gain for ERP is expressed in dBd.
36 dBm EIRP is equivalent to approximately 33.85 dBm ERP.
Systems under ETSI standards are limited to 4W EIRP.
tf.correction: ETSI limits to 2W ERP; FCC limits to 4W EIRP.

tf.q: Power in dBW is equal to Power in dBm minus 30.

mcq.q: What is the term for communication from the RFID reader to the tag?
What is the term for communication from the RFID tag to the reader?
In near-field RFID, communication relies on _______ coupling between the reader and tag.
What is the typical communication range for near-field RFID systems?
Which frequency is used for high-frequency (HF) near-field systems?
Near-field communication uses _______ modulation to encode data.
Far-field RFID communication occurs via _______ wave propagation.
What modulation technique is used by far-field RFID tags?
What is the typical communication range for far-field UHF systems?
UHF far-field communication operates in which frequency range?
RFID-enabled containers in logistics can provide real-time updates on _______ for perishable goods.
What type of collision occurs when coverage areas of two different readers overlap?
When multiple tags in the same zone attempt to transmit data simultaneously, it is a _______ collision.
Which of the following is an impact of RFID signal collisions?
The Aloha algorithm belongs to which class of anti-collision protocols?
Which anti-collision algorithm systematically splits groups based on binary prefixes?
Tree Walking is a standard algorithm used in _______ systems.
What risk involves the unauthorized interception of communication between a reader and tag?
What is the act of using an unauthorized reader to steal tag information like credit card numbers?
Which security risk involves copying data from a legitimate badge onto a blank tag?
Which mitigation technique uses metal sleeves to block electromagnetic fields?
What command is used to permanently disable a retail tag after purchase?
In Sensor Tags, what does BAP stand for?
Which RFID integration detects misplaced items on warehouse shelves automatically?
How can metal interference be mitigated in RFID implementations?
Which material is a major absorber of UHF energy?
To detect tags in any orientation, readers should use _______ polarized antennas.
If a reader uses a linear antenna, how must the tag antenna be aligned?
What is the 'Last Meter' of IoT referred to in the lecture?
opts: RFID giving identity to non-digital objects
mcq.answer: RFID giving identity to non-digital objects

tf.q: Downlink refers to communication from the tag to the reader.
tf.correction: Downlink is from the reader to the tag (R -> T).

tf.q: Near-field communication relies on magnetic fields for operation.
Far-field communication has a shorter range than near-field communication.
tf.correction: Far-field has a longer range (10-15m) compared to near-field (cm to 1m).

tf.q: RFID enhances traceability in industries like pharmaceuticals and food.
Reader collision occurs when multiple tags transmit at the same time.
tf.correction: This is Tag Collision; Reader Collision is when reader coverage areas overlap.

tf.q: In Slotted Aloha, if a collision occurs, tags wait a random interval before retrying.
Encryption (like AES or DES) makes data readable even if eavesdropped.
tf.correction: Encryption makes data unreadable without the proper key.

tf.q: Mutual authentication uses a 'Challenge-Response' mechanism.
Active sensor tags use backscatter for communication.
tf.correction: Battery-Assisted Passive (BAP) tags use backscatter; Active tags transmit directly.

tf.q: Circular polarized antennas detect tags in any orientation but have a slightly reduced range.

mcq.q: What type of waves does wireless communication utilize to carry information?
Which of the following is an example of short-distance wireless communication?
Who demonstrated the first successful wireless transmission using radio waves in 1895?
In which year was the first mobile phone call made?
Which organization introduced the term 'Wi-Fi' in 1999?
What is the typical frequency range for Radio Frequency (RF) waves?
What is the approximate speed of RF waves in a vacuum?
Which frequency band covers 30 MHz to 3 GHz?
What is a primary application of Super High Frequency (SHF) waves (3 GHz - 30 GHz)?
Which propagation mode involves a direct, unobstructed path between transmitter and receiver?
What phenomenon occurs when signals bounce off large surfaces like buildings?
Which phenomenon allows signals to pass around obstacles like hills or buildings?
Scattering is most pronounced for which type of signals?
Which atmospheric layer is responsible for refracting radio waves for long-distance communication?
What phenomenon causes signal degradation due to water vapor or oxygen absorbing radio waves?
The shift in received frequency caused by relative motion between transmitter and receiver is called _______.
Which type of polarization is often used in satellite communications to avoid orientation issues?
In Amplitude Modulation (AM), what characteristic of the carrier wave is varied?
What is a major disadvantage of Amplitude Modulation (AM)?
Which analog modulation technique offers better sound quality and resistance to noise?
In Phase Shift Keying (PSK), what is varied to encode data?
How many bits does BPSK (Binary Phase Shift Keying) represent per symbol?
Quadrature Amplitude Modulation (QAM) is a combination of which two modulation techniques?
How many bits per symbol does 16-QAM transmit?
How many bits per symbol does 64-QAM transmit?
What is a disadvantage of higher-order QAM (e.g., 64-QAM)?
Why are digital signals generally preferred over analog signals regarding noise?
opts: They can be corrected using error detection
mcq.answer: They can be corrected using error detection

mcq.q: Which feature of digital modulation enhances security?
Which digital modulation scheme is known for high data rates and efficient bandwidth usage?
What term describes the phenomenon where rain absorbs or scatters signals in satellite communication?

tf.q: Wireless communication requires a physical medium like cables to transmit signals.
tf.correction: It does not require a physical medium; it uses electromagnetic waves.

tf.q: The first mobile phone call was made using a device called the Motorola DynaTAC 8000X.
Radio waves have shorter wavelengths than Gamma rays.
tf.correction: Radio waves have the longest wavelengths in the spectrum.

tf.q: Line-of-Sight (LOS) communication is ideal for high data rates due to minimal interference.
Multipath propagation occurs when signals are unobstructed and travel in a straight line.
tf.correction: It occurs when signals reflect or diffract, reaching the receiver via multiple paths.

tf.q: Diffraction allows wireless signals to reach areas obstructed by buildings.
Fog and rain have no effect on wireless signal propagation.
tf.correction: They can scatter and absorb signals, affecting performance.

tf.q: In Frequency Modulation (FM), the amplitude of the carrier wave remains constant.
QPSK (Quadrature Phase Shift Keying) represents one bit per phase.
tf.correction: QPSK represents two bits per phase.

tf.q: Digital modulation techniques allow for easier data encryption than analog modulation.
16-QAM uses 16 different frequencies to encode data.
tf.correction: It uses 16 different combinations of amplitude and phase.

tf.q: Doppler shift is crucial in mobile communication due to the relative motion between transmitter and receiver.
AM is more efficient in terms of power and bandwidth than FM.
tf.correction: AM is less efficient in terms of power and bandwidth.

tf.q: Reflection is useful in radar systems.
Mismatched polarization between antennas increases signal strength.
tf.correction: It leads to a reduction in signal strength.

mcq.q: What is the process of combining multiple signals for transmission over a shared channel called?
Which multiplexing technique divides the spectrum into non-overlapping frequency bands?
What is used in FDM to prevent interference between adjacent channels?
Which multiplexing method assigns the entire bandwidth to a user for a specific time duration?
What is a major disadvantage of Time Division Multiplexing (TDM)?
Which technique assigns a unique code to each user to modulate their signal?
Which of the following is an application of CDM/CDMA?
In OFDM, what property allows subcarriers to be spaced closely without interference?
Which multiplexing technique uses multiple antennas at the transmitter and receiver?
What is a disadvantage of Polarization Division Multiplexing (PDM)?
The Friis Transmission Equation describes power reception under which conditions?
In the Friis equation, if the frequency is 300 MHz, what is the wavelength (λ)? (Assume c = 3x10^8 m/s)
Calculate the effective aperture area (Ae) if Gain (Gr) = 10 and Wavelength (λ) = 2 meters.
If the distance (r) is doubled in free space, by what factor does the Path Loss increase (linear scale)?
Calculate the Free-Space Path Loss in dB if the term 20log(4πr/λ) equals 100 dB.
Using the Link Budget formula: If Pt = 20 dBm, Gt = 10 dB, Gr = 10 dB, Lp = 100 dB, and other losses = 0, what is Pr?
In the Link Budget equation, what does 'Ls' represent?
Which formula accounts for real-world losses like cables and fading?
If P_signal = 100 mW and P_noise = 1 mW, what is the SNR?
Calculate the ideal thermal noise power (P_noise) if T = 290 K, B = 10^8 Hz, and k ≈ 1.38 x 10^-23.
What parameter accounts for a receiver's non-ideal performance in noise calculations?
Which application typically uses FDM?
Which application typically uses TDM?
Which application uses OFDM?
Spatial Multiplexing improves reliability through which technique?
In the Link Budget: If Transmitted Power is 30 dBm and Total Loss is 90 dB (Net Gain is 0), what is Received Power?
What is the bandwidth (B) used in the thermal noise formula measured in?
If a transmitter has 10 Watts of power, and losses reduce it to 1 Watt at the receiver, what is the efficiency?
What does 'k' represent in the noise power formula P = kTB?

tf.q: FDM allows multiple signals to be transmitted simultaneously.
TDM assigns unique frequency bands to each user.
tf.correction: TDM assigns time slots, FDM assigns frequency bands.

tf.q: CDM allows multiple users to share the same bandwidth without guard bands.
OFDM is sensitive to frequency offset and Doppler effects.
MIMO increases data rates by requiring additional bandwidth.
tf.correction: MIMO increases rates without additional bandwidth.

tf.q: PDM doubles the capacity of a single frequency.
The Friis Transmission Equation accounts for system-specific losses like cables.
tf.correction: Friis is for idealized free-space conditions.

tf.q: Free-Space Path Loss (Lp) depends on both distance and frequency.
In the Link Budget, Lm stands for Main Losses.
tf.correction: Lm stands for Miscellaneous losses.

tf.q: A higher SNR indicates a stronger signal relative to noise.
The Boltzmann constant is approximately 1.38 x 10^-23 J/K.
If the bandwidth B is zero, the calculated thermal noise power is infinite.
tf.correction: If B is zero, noise power is zero.

tf.q: Spatial Multiplexing uses Single Input Single Output (SISO) antenna configuration.
tf.correction: It uses Multiple Input Multiple Output (MIMO).

tf.q: Link Budget is used for troubleshooting communication systems.
Power density S is inversely proportional to the square of the distance r.

mcq.q: What type of communication enables users to access information and make voice calls while on the move?
Which generation of mobile communications primarily focused on analog voice transmission?
What type of modulation was used for voice transmission in 1G?
In 1G networks, calls were established via which switching method?
What was the typical frequency range for 1G operations?
Which multiple access technique was used in 1G systems?
Which device is an example of a 1G mobile phone?
Which of the following was a major limitation of 1G?
Which generation introduced digital communication?
What was the content of the first-ever SMS sent in 1992?
Which standard was developed by ETSI and launched in 1991?
GSM operated in which frequency bands?
What component is used for user identification in GSM?
Which 2G technology used spread-spectrum technology?
What data speed did GPRS offer?
What technology is often referred to as 2.75G?
Which generation marked the transition from voice-centric to data-driven applications?
What was the range of initial data speeds for 3G?
3G combined packet-switched technology for data with what for voice?
Which of the following is a unified standard for 3G global roaming?
Which frequency band was commonly used in 3G operation?
What was a major limitation regarding power in 3G devices?
Which application became possible with 3G multimedia support?
What maximum data speed could EDGE provide?
What does MSC stand for in the context of mobile network architecture?
Which generation was the first to support international roaming?
Why was 1G communication prone to eavesdropping?
Which access technique divides the spectrum into distinct frequency bands for each user?
3G became insufficient for which application, leading to its replacement?

tf.q: 1G systems were primarily focused on digital voice transmission.
tf.correction: 1G focused on analog voice transmission.

tf.q: 1G communication was secure due to advanced encryption.
tf.correction: 1G lacked encryption and was prone to eavesdropping.

tf.q: The first 1G systems were implemented widely during the 1980s.
2G introduced Short Message Service (SMS).
GSM uses Code Division Multiple Access (CDMA) for channel allocation.
tf.correction: GSM uses Time Division Multiple Access (TDMA).

tf.q: Digital signals in 2G consumed more power than analog signals in 1G.
tf.correction: Digital signals consumed less power, improving battery life.

tf.q: GPRS enabled packet-switched data transmission in 2G networks.
3G networks supported data speeds up to 100 Mbps initially.
tf.correction: Initial 3G speeds ranged from 144 kbps to 2 Mbps.

tf.q: 3G technology facilitated video-on-demand and mobile TV.
One limitation of 3G was the high cost of infrastructure deployment.
1G devices relied on primitive battery technology leading to short battery life.
CDMA was introduced as a competitor to GSM in the 2G era.
EDGE provided lower data speeds compared to GPRS.
tf.correction: EDGE provided higher data speeds (up to 384 kbps) than GPRS.

tf.q: 3G maintained connectivity while moving at high speeds, such as in trains.
The Motorola DynaTAC 8000X is an example of a 2G device.
tf.correction: It is an example of a 1G device.

mcq.q: When were 4G networks first deployed?
What type of switching architecture does 4G use?
What is the peak 4G speed for stationary users?
What is the peak 4G speed for mobile users?
4G reduced latency to under what value?
Which technology is the foundation of LTE data transmission?
What is the theoretical peak download speed of standard LTE?
What feature did LTE-Advanced introduce to boost throughput?
What is the theoretical peak download speed of LTE-Advanced?
Which 4G technology was an alternative to LTE before LTE became dominant?
What frequency range defines the 5G Low Band?
Which 5G band is ideal for balancing coverage and speed in urban areas?
What is the frequency range for 5G mmWave (High Band)?
What is the maximum download speed of 5G?
To what value is latency reduced in 5G?
Which 5G technology uses hundreds of antennas at base stations?
Which 5G application supports remote surgery?
What is a major limitation of 5G mmWave signals?
Which environmental factor can degrade high-frequency 5G signals?
What is the predicted data rate for 6G?
What frequency bands will 6G utilize?
What is the expected latency for 6G?
How many connected devices can 6G support?
Which technology will 6G use for dynamic network optimization?
What type of video communication does 6G support?
What is a significant challenge for 6G regarding components?
What does VoLTE stand for?
Which 4G limitation affects rural areas most?
5G enables which industrial concept?

tf.q: 4G networks are entirely packet-switched.
4G latency is typically around 100 ms.
tf.correction: 4G latency is reduced to under 10 ms.

tf.q: VoLTE allows voice calls without switching to 2G/3G networks.
5G Low Band offers the highest speeds but lowest coverage.
tf.correction: Low Band offers wide coverage with slower speeds.

tf.q: 5G uses carrier aggregation to increase total bandwidth.
Millimeter wave (mmWave) signals can easily pass through buildings.
tf.correction: They are easily blocked by obstacles like walls and buildings.

tf.q: 5G consumes more power per transmitted bit than 4G.
tf.correction: It is optimized for lower power consumption per bit.

tf.q: 6G is expected to achieve latencies below 100 microseconds.
6G will utilize frequencies between 1 GHz and 6 GHz.
tf.correction: 6G will utilize frequencies between 100 GHz and 10 THz.

tf.q: 6G networks will be driven by Artificial Intelligence.
Developing 6G technology is expected to be low cost.
tf.correction: It is expected to be highly capital-intensive.

tf.q: 4G offered peak speeds of up to 10 Gbps.
tf.correction: 4G offered up to 1 Gbps; 5G offers up to 10 Gbps.

tf.q: Massive MIMO in 5G improves network capacity.
WiMAX is the most widely adopted 4G technology.
tf.correction: LTE is the most widely adopted 4G technology.

tf.q: 6G supports holographic communications.
